persona.name: Isla Moreno-Grant

occupation.title: Middle School English Teacher (Grades 6-8)
occupation.organization: Seattle Public Schools, Jefferson Middle School
occupation.description: Full-time public middle school English teacher in an urban school. Primary responsibilities: plan and deliver standards-based lessons in literature and writing, differentiate instruction for English learners and students with IEPs, coordinate with ESL specialists and special education staff, design project-based assessments, grade assignments, and provide timely feedback. Runs an after-school book club twice a week and organizes a monthly family literacy night in collaboration with the school librarian. Supervises advisory groups, handles parent conferences, attends professional development days, and helps develop the school's culturally responsive curriculum. Skills include classroom management, formative assessment design, scaffolding reading comprehension strategies, restorative conferencing, and designing lessons that blend print and digital literacies. She frequently uses Google Classroom, Canvas, and online reading platforms; prepares rubrics; and liaises with counselors when students show signs of trauma or chronic absenteeism. Typical workplace challenges: crowded classrooms (28–32 students), limited prep time, balancing administrative demands with individualized instruction, and advocating for resources for bilingual learners.

persona.education: B.A. in English with Secondary Education Certification, University of Washington. Completed a one-year teaching credential program and a summer ESL methods course. Has taken continuing-education workshops in trauma-informed classroom practice, restorative justice in schools, and adolescent literacy interventions.
long_term_goals: To become a tenured middle-school English teacher and lead curriculum development for culturally responsive literature programs.
To buy a modest rowhouse or condo in a walkable neighborhood close to parks and community resources.
To have a stable family life while maintaining time for hobbies: reading, board gaming nights, and travel.
To build a small community literacy nonprofit that pairs bilingual volunteers with immigrant families for reading support.
To travel through Spain and Mexico to connect with family heritage and practice Spanish regional dialects.
To cultivate financial security (emergency fund, retirement savings) and pay off student loans within 10 years.
To mentor new teachers and be recognized as a reliable, empathetic leader in the district.
To maintain physical and mental health routines so she can age independently.
To keep expanding her personal library to include diverse voices and obscure translations.
To pass on a love of games and reading to future children or godchildren.

style.general: Warm, pragmatic, and conversational with a subtle West Coast cadence. She blends casual friendliness with professional clarity when needed.
style.speech: Speaks with a Pacific Northwest / Seattle accent: relatively flattened vowels, relaxed intonation. Codeswitches fluidly between English and conversational Spanish when with family, colleagues, or bilingual students. Uses teacher-talk vocabulary ("exit ticket," "scaffold," "learning target") in professional settings, and more colloquial phrases ("That's sweet," "No worries") with friends.
style.mannerisms: Tilts her head when listening intently, folds arms briefly when thinking aloud, tucks hair behind her ear while reading, and makes frequent eye contact. When nervous or excited she'll nervously play with the elastic band on her wrist or tap her thumb against her phone. She smiles easily and uses short, clear directives in class. Has a habit of humming soft indie-folk songs while shelving books.
style.dress: Smart-casual teacher wardrobe: comfortable cardigans, midi dresses layered with leggings in cooler months, sensible ankle boots. When outdoors she favors a lightweight rain jacket and a waxed canvas tote for work materials. In social settings she wears vintage-inspired jewelry — a silver locket that belonged to her maternal grandmother.
style.digital_presence: Moderate social media use: active on Instagram for personal photos and a private Facebook group for her book club. Keeps LinkedIn professional but sparingly updated. Uses an organized Google Drive for lesson plans and a digital planner to coordinate family and school life.

Practices therapy intermittently (cognitive-behavioral based counseling), journaling, and breathing exercises. Uses sleep hygiene practices but occasionally has trouble falling asleep before big school days.
health.medical_history: No major surgeries. Childhood asthma that resolved in late teens. Regular dental and gynecological checkups. Has taken short-term antibiotics in the past few years for routine infections.
health.lifestyle: Non-smoker, drinks socially (1–2 glasses of wine on weekends), eats a largely balanced diet with vegetarian-leaning meals several days a week. Tries to limit processed foods. Prioritizes mental-health days when possible.

other_facts: Full name reflects bicultural heritage: Moreno from her mother's family (Mexican) and Grant from her father's side (British descent).
Grew up in a bilingual household where Spanish was spoken at family meals and English at school.
Spent summers in Guadalajara with maternal relatives, learning family recipes and local storytelling traditions.
First job at 16: worked at a neighborhood used-bookstore, which deepened her love for scraped-spine paperbacks and recommending titles to strangers.
Was the class valedictorian in high school for thoughtful speeches and community volunteer hours.
Started collecting board games in college as a way to make friends and found it became a lasting social glue.
Has a small tattoo of an open book on her left forearm, done on a whim after graduation; meaningful as a lifelong reminder to keep learning.
Luna, her rescue dog, was adopted from a neighborhood rescue when Isla moved into her first apartment after college.
Used to be a competitive swimmer through middle school but stopped in high school to focus on theater and debate.
Volunteered in a summer literacy camp during college that shaped her desire to teach middle-school students.
Once organized a successful 'literature and tacos' fundraiser for the school library that raised funds for new bilingual picture books.
Is frugal with big-ticket purchases: waits months to research appliances, travel deals, and housing options before committing.
Has student loan debt estimated in the mid five figures and contributes monthly to a targeted payoff plan while also contributing to a small retirement account.
Is politically engaged at the local level — attends town halls on school budgets and occasionally volunteers for school board candidate campaigns she supports.
Was once interviewed for a local newspaper about her school's after-school book club.
Participated in a teacher-exchange program for two weeks in Barcelona during a summer between teaching years, which improved her Spanish and gave curricular ideas.
Keeps an emergency binder with medical info, a phone list, and key student accommodations for substitute teachers.
Is allergic to cats but tolerates them in short visits; currently prefers dogs because of fewer allergens for her.
Has a favorite neighborhood bench where she writes lesson reflections and sometimes meets students for informal check-ins.
Is an avid list-maker and keeps separate lists for books-to-teach, books-to-read-for-fun, games-to-buy, and recipes-to-try.
Has a signature weekend breakfast: scrambled eggs with salsa verde and corn tortillas, a recipe she learned from her mother.
Practices mindfulness breathing before parent conferences or when grading a stack of essays to keep emotions even.
Once rescued a student's family from eviction by connecting them to a rental-assistance nonprofit through a colleague network.
Has run a mock 'publishing house' project: students create a class anthology of short stories and manage editing, design, and a public reading night.
Collects postcards from places she visits and pins them on a map above her desk; entries include a postcard from Oaxaca and one from a seaside town in Wales.
Is ambidextrous in small ways: writes neatly with her right hand but often draws and sketches with her left.
Keeps a 'comfort box' in class with fidget toys, stress balls, and a few favorite picture books for students who need calming time.
Has a low-key superstition of wearing a particular navy cardigan for important observations and evaluations.
Was once nearly late to her wedding because Luna chewed through a shoe; the story remains a favorite at parties.
Grew up watching telenovelas with her grandmother and now appreciates dramatic storytelling as a resource for teaching narrative structure.
Has a close relationship with a retired aunt who taught her traditional embroidery; she sometimes uses textiles as creative prompts in class.
Takes a yearly 'reading fast' week (no social media, mostly reading) to reset focus and choose next-year curricula.
Keeps a small succulent garden on her windowsill and finds plant care soothing on rainy Seattle afternoons.
Can play a couple of chords on a second-hand acoustic guitar and uses music in class to set mood for readings.
Was once on a local radio segment discussing why middle-schoolers need more exposure to diverse literature.
Has a superstition of always carrying a small penknife (utility tool) in her bag for quick classroom fixes — never for harm.
Attends an annual board-game convention with friends and takes notes on game mechanics that encourage cooperation for classroom activities.
Maintains a personal oral-history archive — recorded conversations with family elders about migration, recipes, and childhood stories — used sometimes in class as primary-source material.
Won a district award for an innovative culturally responsive unit on coming-of-age stories that combined student's family narratives with canonical texts.
Keeps a 'teacher survival kit' in her classroom: extra pens, snacks, pre-cut sticky notes, spare clothes, and a rechargeable phone battery.
Likes to celebrate small milestones with students — a pizza party after a marathon writing week, or a cake when a student completes a challenging reading.
Once declined a promotion to an administrative role because she preferred classroom teaching and direct student contact.
Dreams of writing a middle-grade novel someday based on her students' stories blended with magical realism elements.
